title: Gg - Fonts with a cool G/g letterform
content:
I'm going to open a can-o-worms here. I think the letter 'g' is one of the few characters that really stand out in a type face. There are a multitude of ways it can be crafted. With so many fonts out there, I look at a few letters -- the lowercase g in particular.

This is how I propose the thread will work. I'm not here to militarize things... just some friend standardization.  
1. Go to a font site (I prefer [http://www.fontshop.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/ "http://www.fontshop.com/") because you can link to samples)  
2. Find your font  
3. Post a link to it (if possible to the sample) along with the font name.

For example:

Natalie Script OT  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/paratype/natali\_script\_ot/?sampl...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/paratype/natali_script_ot/?sample_text=Gg&sample_size=36 "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/paratype/natali\_script\_ot/?sample\_text=Gg&sample\_size=36")

You can also post an image. Let's see your G-sus.
author: Artform

comments.content: Here are two: [Relato bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/emtype/relato_bold/?sample_text=Gg&sample_size=36) and [Relato Sans bold italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/emtype/relato_sans_bold_italic_ot/?sample_text=Gg&sample_size=36)
[Arrighi](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/centaur_italic_std/?sample_text=Gg&sample_size=36): I really like earless italic gs.

Jigsaw has a cool lowercase g  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/typotheque/jigsaw\_solid\_bundle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/typotheque/jigsaw_solid_bundle/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/typotheque/jigsaw\_solid\_bundle/")

Strangely, the g in Missionary seems to derive from one of the two extraordinary alternate gs in Renner's original Futura, which I was just about to post:

[Architype Renner](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.foundrytypes.co.uk/foundry_architype_1/renner.html) (sorry, tiny showing).

Plus:

[Didot Elder](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.optimo.ch/pages/departement/index.php?id_categorie=1&id_font=9)

Porchez's [Ambroise](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/porchez/ambroise_regular/?sample_text=g&sample_size=310) has the same kind of lowercase g (without the arrowheads on G).

Hey, my post has moved down again.
May I say the best g ever is Baskerville's? (and some of the worst are Benguiat's).

I'd like to bend the rules a bit and post [one of the worst lowercase 'g's](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043040/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ascender/trebuchet/regular/mac-t1/298873/character/0067/CP4/1/) known in the history of man. :^P

I agree about the Baskerville "g," and of course Renner's original/alternate Futura "g."
